pullRequest.body:
Allows PGame options to be removed. To build up to the replacement lemma, necessary for the equivalence of games to their undominated selves.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [47c2d8de15](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20170/commits/47c2d8de15c762dc3f9272bbba47ced2aca38685)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ neg_removeRight_neg`
`+ removeLeft`
`+ removeLeft_le`
`+ removeRight`
`+ removeRight_le`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
I would like to prove that for some game G, inserting an option x' then removing x' is identical to G, but I'm unsure about the best way to structure this.
This came up during the triage meeting for the second time in a row. Violeta, could you either review or absorb this PR into the soon-to-be-created combinatorial game theory repo?
I've been really busy these past days. I'll try to properly review this within the next week or so.
So is the proposal that we close this PR and it will be moved to the CGT repo?
Instead of `x' : PGame`, I think you should take `i : x.LeftMoves` as an argument.
Interesting! I expected it to worsen the proofs, but it helped remove dealing with HEq!

As the `leftMoves_neg` docstring suggests, you should instead use [`SetTheory.PGame.toLeftMovesNeg`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Game/PGame.html#SetTheory.PGame.toLeftMovesNeg) to cast between both types.
I remember trying `toLeftMovesNeg` before and encountering an issue, but it works fine with `toLeftMovesNeg`. Fixed :+1:
Same here.
Is this definition really what you want? Remember that `PGame` equality is a very strong relation. Perhaps ` Identical x i` makes more sense?
I might move this PR to `Game`: I wanted to have this for the replacement lemma, which operates under `PGame.setoid`.

I think this is fine? `i` is an element in `x.LeftMoves`, it's not a PGame.
```suggestion
  | mk _ xr xL xR => mk { x // x  i } xr (xL ) xR
```
(untested)

The suggestion works (with an extra `val` cast)

> I think this is fine? `i` is an element in `x.LeftMoves`, it's not a PGame.

The main problem is that the strict equality means `removeLeft` is well defined for `PGame`, but for what I wanted, it wouldn't work well if I was strictly *trying* to remove an option. I think this PR is fine, but this is part of the many code duplication issues between `PGame` / a potential `IGame` / `Game`.

(For example, if I had a game that had a left type with two possible instances, and both instances mapped to 0, removing one instance of `x.LeftMoves` wouldn't actually change the value: x would still be identical to x.removeLeft x' in this scenario)
[I've mentioned this duplication issue in Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/116395-maths/topic/What.20to.20do.20about.20PGame/near/491135352).

For that purpose it's probably appropriate to use equality (or inequality) in Game. If you remove all identical options, but some option with the same value remains, you still don't change the value of x.

> For that purpose it's probably appropriate to use equality (or inequality) in Game. If you remove all identical options, but some option with the same value remains, you still don't change the value of x.

Absolutely. Though I do think there might be some value in keeping this definition for `PGame` and having a separate definition for `Game`. However, that decision entirely depends on how `PGame`/`IGame` refactoring goes.
After some more Zulip conversation, it seems appropriate to keep this `PGame.removeLeft`/`PGame.removeRight`, and have corresponding remove APIs for `IGame` and `Game`.

I just realized my initial complaint in this thread doesn't even typecheck. So here's a question that hopefully makes sense. Do we want to remove `i : x.leftMoves`, i.e. some branch of the game tree, or do we want to remove some `PGame`, i.e. all branches leading to said game? I think the latter notion is the one that generalizes to `IGame`, which might be reason to use it here too.

Specifically, I'm suggesting something like
```lean 4
def removeLeft (x y : PGame.{u}) : PGame :=
  match x with
  | mk _ xr xL xR => mk {i //  x.moveLeft i  y} xr (fun k  xL k.val) xR
```
The nice thing about this is that we could then define `IGame.removeLeft` as the [`Quotient.lift`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Init/Core.html#Quotient.lift%E2%82%82) of `PGame.removeLeft`. The disadvantage (if you want to see it that way) is that we're now allowing the no-op "removal" of options that aren't even there.

[I should clarify that I used this definition in my first commit](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20170/commits/604b823eed89310dcec03863ee3fd0b51e94fe7c#diff-062c235c26c997670d8272c5536d9dd08a7c4b624a51b659b0e73fcc635bacbdR1908-R1910). I can revert to this definition and use the same proofs :+1:
IMO that would be best, but it might be worth getting a second opinion.
Who do you suggest might give this second opinion? I'm in the triage party and this PR came up.
Good point, I think Tristan and I are the only currently active contributors to Mathlib game theory. So we can skip the second opinion.

pullRequest.title: feat(SetTheory/Game/PGame): removing options
